document_metadata.title: Uncertainty Register - Talent vs System Constraints

uncertainty_register.unknown: Actual attrition rates and turnover patterns in heroic execution zones (support staff, operations teams, delivery teams)
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: Cannot quantify talent stability risk precisely. Inferred support staff attrition from customer satisfaction decline (Trustpilot 'consistently worse' 2024) and heroics dependency ('dozens of engineers' coordination BBB)—but actual turnover rate unknown. Inferred operations team burnout risk from multi-month sustained crises (ransomware, zero-day)—but actual attrition unknown. Cannot assess whether turnover accelerating or stable. Cannot determine death spiral timeline—how quickly heroics-driven attrition compounds? Cannot prioritize retention interventions—which roles have highest attrition risk requiring immediate action? Cannot model talent availability—if attrition rate X%, can organization recruit replacements at sustainable rate or does backlog accumulate?
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: Attrition data by function and role: Support staff annual turnover rate (last 3 years trend), operations/security team turnover rate, delivery team turnover rate, voluntary vs involuntary attrition breakdown, regrettable vs non-regrettable turnover assessment, exit interview data citing workload/burnout/heroics as factors, time-to-fill metrics for critical roles (recruiting difficulty indicator), internal promotion vs external hiring ratios, tenure distribution by role (concentration of short vs long tenure)

uncertainty_register.unknown: Tribal knowledge concentration and documentation gaps—extent of undocumented operational knowledge
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: Cannot quantify knowledge transfer risk magnitude. Inferred legacy system custodian tribal knowledge from 15+ year operational history, three ownership transitions, technical debt accumulation (Stage 4.4)—but documentation extent unknown. Inferred support coordination knowledge tribal from informal 'dozens of engineers' coordination—but what percentage of procedures documented vs tribal? Cannot assess turnover impact severity—if key custodian departs, how long until replacement achieves competence? Weeks? Months? Years? Cannot determine whether knowledge transfer feasible—if documentation created, can tribal knowledge be captured or is complexity too high? Cannot prioritize documentation efforts—which areas have highest knowledge concentration risk requiring immediate documentation?
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: Knowledge documentation assessment: Comprehensive operations runbook completeness audit (what percentage of procedures documented?), legacy system documentation inventory (architecture diagrams, configuration documentation, operational procedures, vendor integration documentation), support cross-functional coordination procedures documentation, multi-jurisdictional deployment procedures documentation by jurisdiction, incident response runbook completeness by incident type, key person risk assessment (which specific individuals possess critical undocumented knowledge?), knowledge transfer time estimates (how long to train replacement in each critical role?), documentation creation feasibility assessment (can tribal knowledge be captured or is complexity irreducible?)

uncertainty_register.unknown: Burnout severity and sustainability timeline in heroic execution zones
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: Cannot assess when heroics capacity exhausts catastrophically. Inferred CEO burnout from three transitions in three years—but was each CEO departure burnout-driven or Board-driven? Inferred operations burnout risk from multi-month crises—but can teams sustain or is attrition imminent? Inferred support burnout from coordination overhead—but how close to capacity limit? Cannot determine intervention urgency—are heroic zones sustainable for months? Quarters? Years? Or already at breaking point? Cannot assess intervention effectiveness required—incremental improvement sufficient or radical restructuring necessary? Cannot predict failure mode—does heroics capacity degrade gradually (increasing error rate, declining satisfaction) or collapse suddenly (mass attrition, catastrophic incident)?
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: Workforce health and sustainability assessment: Employee engagement survey data (burnout indicators, satisfaction with workload, intent to stay), health and wellness metrics if available (stress-related absence, overtime hours by role), workforce capacity utilization assessment (what percentage operating at sustainable vs heroic levels?), manager assessment of team sustainability (can teams maintain current pace? For how long?), near-miss incident analysis (errors or failures indicating capacity stress), overtime and on-call rotation sustainability (extended hours patterns indicating unsustainable load), succession risk assessment (how many critical roles have viable successors?)

uncertainty_register.unknown: Capability gaps preventing effective delegation and authority distribution
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: Cannot assess whether structural reforms would succeed given current talent capability. Inferred BU Presidents lack coordination capability from authority concentration with CEO—but is capability absent or untested because authority withheld? If BU Presidents granted cross-functional authority, would they exercise effectively or recreate coordination failures? Inferred support staff could leverage formal authority if granted (attempting resolution despite authority gap)—but would VP Support role succeed or fail? Cannot determine structural reform sequencing—must capability be developed before authority delegated, or does authority delegation enable capability development? Cannot assess build vs buy decision—develop existing leaders' capability through authority delegation and learning, or recruit external leaders with proven capability?
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: Leadership capability assessment: BU President coordination skills evaluation (can they negotiate peer conflicts, optimize enterprise vs local, manage cross-functional dependencies?), support leadership capability assessment (can they compel cross-functional action, resolve authority conflicts, prioritize effectively?), sales leadership profitability analysis capability (can they assess delivery cost, negotiate value-based pricing, conduct buildability validation?), operations leadership prevention capability (can they design proactive controls, prioritize prevention investment, measure effectiveness?), executive bench strength assessment (if current leaders insufficient, are successors available internally?), leadership development program maturity (can organization develop capabilities or require external recruitment?), external talent market assessment (if external recruitment needed, are candidates available?)

uncertainty_register.unknown: Structural reform implementation capacity—organizational change absorption capability
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: Cannot assess whether organization can absorb structural reforms even if capability exists. Multiple structural gaps identified: No operating committee (Stage 4.1), no deal review board (Stage 4.1), no VP Support (Stage 4.1), no CRO (Stage 4.1), incentive structure misalignments (Stage 4.4), authority-accountability voids (Stage 4.4). If all gaps addressed simultaneously—organizational change overload risk. If gaps addressed sequentially—which sequence optimal and what timeline required? Cannot assess reform resistance—will functions resist authority reallocation (sales resist profitability veto, engineering resist operations stability authority, BU Presidents resist enterprise coordination)? Cannot assess reform investment feasibility—capital constrained ($1.3B debt), can fund governance infrastructure creation, incentive realignment transition costs, leadership capability development?
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: Organizational change capacity assessment: Recent change management track record (what major changes attempted? Outcomes?), cultural change readiness assessment (receptivity to authority reallocation, incentive changes, governance creation), reform prioritization and sequencing analysis (which reforms most critical? Which prerequisite for others?), reform investment requirements (governance infrastructure cost, incentive transition cost, capability development cost), capital availability for transformation (can absorb within debt constraints?), leadership bandwidth for change management (can existing leaders manage business continuity AND transformation?), change fatigue assessment (three CEOs, multiple reorganizations—is organization exhausted or resilient?)

uncertainty_register.unknown: Post-acquisition integration strategy impact on talent stability and structural reform feasibility
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: All talent deployment and structural reform analysis assumes Rackspace continues as going concern—but M&A context means acquirer integration approach will determine relevance. If full integration—Rackspace talent may be redundant to acquirer, acquirer systems replace Rackspace structural gaps. If standalone operation—Rackspace structural reforms critical for value realization. If asset cherry-picking—talent in retained assets critical, talent in divested assets irrelevant. Talent stability at risk during acquisition: Key talent may depart pre-close (uncertainty drives attrition), acquirer may eliminate roles (redundancy to acquirer capabilities), integration may create additional heroics demand (parallel legacy and acquirer systems). Cannot plan talent retention or structural reform without knowing integration approach. Investment in pre-close structural reform risky—may be wasted if acquirer replaces systems. But failure to reform may reduce value—acquirer values stable business not talent-dependent fragility.
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: UNKNOWABLE until acquirer identified and integration strategy negotiated. Can model scenarios: (1) Full integration—talent retention plan for key individuals during transition, knowledge transfer to acquirer teams, structural reforms low priority (acquirer systems replace), (2) Standalone—structural reforms critical, talent retention essential, organizational stability premium value driver, (3) Asset carve-out—talent retention in retained assets only, structural reforms scoped to retained business. Can conduct talent flight risk assessment: Which key individuals likely to depart pre-close (CEO uncertainty, heroics zones, market-attractive skills)? Can develop retention strategy by scenario: What retention mechanisms by integration approach?
